physicalAI.definition: A branch of artificial intelligence that focuses on AI systems that exist and operate in the physical world, as opposed to traditional digital AI that operates in virtual environments.

humanoidRobotics.definition: A field of robotics that focuses on creating robots with human-like form and capabilities.

ros2.definition: Robot Operating System 2 - middleware for robotics development (acronym kept in English)

gazebo.definition: A 3D simulation environment for robotics development

nvidiaIsaac.definition: NVIDIA's robotics platform for AI-powered robots

vla.definition: Models that combine visual perception, language understanding, and action execution in robotics

embodiedAI.definition: AI systems that have a physical form and interact with the physical world

robotOperatingSystem.definition: Middleware that provides services for robotics software development

simulationEnvironment.definition: A virtual environment used to test and develop robotic systems

computerVision.definition: Field of AI that enables computers to interpret and understand visual information

machineLearning.definition: Subset of AI that enables systems to learn and improve from experience

deepLearning.definition: Subset of machine learning using neural networks with multiple layers

neuralNetwork.definition: Computational model inspired by biological neural networks

reinforcementLearning.definition: Type of machine learning focused on how agents should take actions in an environment

motionPlanning.definition: Computational problem of finding a sequence of valid configurations to move an object

pathPlanning.definition: Computational process of finding a collision-free path from start to goal

controlTheory.definition: Engineering field that deals with the behavior of dynamical systems

feedbackControl.definition: Control system that uses feedback to adjust its behavior

kinematics.definition: Branch of mechanics that deals with motion without considering forces

dynamics.definition: Branch of mechanics concerned with forces and their relation to motion

inverseKinematics.definition: Mathematical process to determine joint parameters for a desired end-effector position

forwardKinematics.definition: Mathematical process to determine end-effector position from joint parameters

endEffector.definition: Device at the end of a robotic arm designed to interact with the environment

degreesOfFreedom.definition: Number of independent movements a mechanical system can make

actuator.definition: Component that moves or controls a mechanism or system

sensor.definition: Device that detects or measures a physical property and records, indicates, or otherwise responds to it

lidar.definition: Light Detection and Ranging - remote sensing method using light in the form of a pulsed laser

imu.definition: Inertial Measurement Unit - device that measures and reports velocity, orientation, and gravitational forces

computerVision.definition: Field of AI that enables computers to interpret and understand visual information

pointCloud.definition: Set of data points in space, generally used to represent 3D shapes

pcl.definition: Point Cloud Library - open source library for 2D/3D image and point cloud processing

tensorflow.definition: Open source platform for machine learning

pytorch.definition: Open source machine learning library based on the Torch library

gpt.definition: Generative Pre-trained Transformer - type of AI model for natural language processing

transformer.definition: Deep learning model that uses attention mechanisms to process sequential data

attentionMechanism.definition: Deep learning technique that helps models focus on relevant parts of input

ar.definition: Technology that superimposes computer-generated content onto the real world

hri.definition: Field studying interaction between humans and robots

embodiedCognition.definition: Theory that cognitive processes are influenced by the body's interactions with the environment

affordance.definition: Property of an object that defines how it can be used

multimodal.definition: Involving multiple modes of input or output (e.g., vision, language, touch)

realTime.definition: System that processes data and responds within a guaranteed timeframe

latency.definition: Time delay between a stimulus and response

bandwidth.definition: Maximum rate of data transfer across a network path

throughput.definition: Amount of material or items passing through a system per unit time

concurrency.definition: Ability of different parts or units of a program to run simultaneously

parallelProcessing.definition: Type of computation in which many calculations are carried out simultaneously
